fields.text: Which of the following is an automated build tool?
fields.answerC: make

fields.text: Which of the following is a cloud service provider?
fields.answerC: Google Cloud Services

fields.text: What is our main tool for communication in our course?
fields.answerC: Kubernetes

fields.text: Lean and agile development displaced the ____ model of development?
fields.answerC: all-at-once

fields.text: We develop incrementally because it....?
fields.answerC: delivers value to the customers faster

fields.text: Version control is an important part of incremental development because...?
fields.answerA: it allows us to roll back changes easily
fields.answerB: it permits auditors to see how much work has been done
fields.answerC: "if you don't know your past you won't know your future."

fields.text: We want to automate our builds because...?
fields.answerC: it allows engineers to do more interesting work

fields.text: An advantage of documenting a process by automating it versus writing a document about how it is done is that...?
fields.answerA: scripts are easier to read than prose
fields.answerB: it gives programmers an edge over tech writers in producing the documentation
fields.answerC: the script can't be out of date with the process, while a text description can be

fields.text: We want to regard our infrastructure as software because...?
fields.answerA: that is what Bill Gates would do
fields.answerB: that allows us to automate that provisioning of infrastructure
fields.answerC: software is cool, while hardware is not

fields.text: Containers can best be conceived as...?
fields.answerB: a different way to test software
fields.answerC: lightweight virtual machines

fields.text: The division of labor is cited by Adam Smith as...?
fields.answerC: make workers smarter

fields.text: One of the reasons the Waterfall Model often fails is...?
fields.answerB: the stages are not separated clearly enough in the model
fields.answerC: we often only realize what software we need to build in the process of building it

fields.text: The DevOps idea of incremental development can be seen as an extension of...?
fields.answerC: an all-at-once development style

fields.text: When we set out to develop software, we...?
fields.answerA: usually know all we need to know at the start
fields.answerB: can easily plan everything in advance
fields.answerC: should lock down all requirements right away
fields.answerD: rarely know all we need to know at the start

fields.text: In software engineering, "MVP" stands for...?
fields.answerC: major vehicle production

fields.text: In the Lean paradigm of development, decisions about the product should be made...?
fields.answerC: as late as possible

fields.text: The term "DevOps" was created by combining the terms...?
fields.answerC: devilish and operatic

fields.text: DevOps can be understood as the need for _____ to keep up with ______ development practices.
fields.answerC: development, operations

fields.text: The advantages of incremental development include...?
fields.answerA: value is delivered to customers more rapidly
fields.answerC: programmer job satisfaction increases

fields.text: Automated testing is an important part of DevOps because...?
fields.answerA: It enables rapid deployment of new software
fields.answerB: "Automated" has a nice sound to it
fields.answerC: It saves money in hiring testers.

fields.text: Testing should be done on...?
fields.answerA: only the most crucial code in the application
fields.answerC: all of the application code AND all of the infrastructure code

fields.text: In DevOps, "silos" refers to the fact that...?
fields.answerA: departments in organizations often seemed sealed off from each other
fields.answerB: good software should be divided into "silos"
fields.answerC: granaries are major users of software

fields.text: We want to script our environment so that...?
fields.answerA: environments are always in a known state
fields.answerB: we lessen the chance that knowledge is locked in team members' heads
fields.answerC: deployments are more predictable and repeatable

fields.text: "Chaos Monkey" is...?
fields.answerA: a tool Netflix developed to intentionally crash their servers
fields.answerB: a description of who is in charge of most software projects
fields.answerC: the state of infrastructure before DevOps

fields.text: The right artifacts of a project to put under version control are...?
fields.answerB: scripts to build the project infrastructure
fields.answerC: project documentation

fields.text: If we version control everything about our project, we...?
fields.answerA: create a big mess no one could understand
fields.answerC: establish a single source of truth for the system
fields.answerD: clog our version control system with trivial stuff

fields.text: Who should have "ownership" (be able to change) parts of a product in an agile team?
fields.answerA: only the creator of that part
fields.answerC: only the project supervisor

fields.text: A poly-skilled engineer
fields.answerC: knows all parts of the technology their team uses

fields.text: An advantage Slack has over email threads is
fields.answerA: people can join and leave threads as they need to
fields.answerB: people won't forget to include someone who needs to see a message
fields.answerC: it is easy to bring in a new person and have them pick up on the whole conversation

fields.text: git and GitHub are...?
fields.answerA: just different names for the same software
fields.answerB: very different: git is the basic version control software, while GitHub is a place to store git repos
fields.answerC: entirely unrelated

fields.text: Commit messages in git are...?
fields.answerA: important to communicate to team members what you are up to
fields.answerC: can be the same for every commit

fields.text: We use "git clone" to...?
fields.answerA: add a clone of a file to a repo
fields.answerB: turn one repo into two repos
fields.answerC: make a local copy of a repo

fields.text: If we see text like "<<<<< HEAD:file.txt" inserted into a file, that is...?
fields.answerB: a UNIX command accidentally inserted in the file
fields.answerC: git showing us where a conflict is in file.txt

fields.text: If you type 'git pull origin master' then master is...?
fields.answerB: the level of difficulty of the pull
fields.answerC: the repo you are pulling from
fields.answerD: how much git should try to force the pull

fields.text: Incremental and iterative development were a response to failures in...?
fields.answerC: test-driven development

fields.text: The problem with describing a server setup in a detailed document is...?
fields.answerA: an engineer has to manually do the setup
fields.answerB: the document will get out of date
fields.answerC: the document is likely to miss some "obvious" step

fields.text: Automated deployment should be coupled with...?
fields.answerB: manual steps to make sure the sys admin is on their toes
fields.answerC: manual configuration

fields.text: Kanban is a method of managing work that...?
fields.answerC: implements a pull system for taking on new work

fields.text: Over-production is a waste because...?
fields.answerB: we are producing something the customer may never need
fields.answerC: we can make more profit from under-production

fields.text: Working in small batches means...?
fields.answerC: risk is reduced

fields.text: Small batches enabled Toyota to...?
fields.answerA: respond more quickly to customer demand
fields.answerB: fit the batches into their small factory
fields.answerC: fire workers more easily

fields.text: You should measure your productivity by...?
fields.answerA: the amount of tasks you are working on
fields.answerC: the amount of tasks you finish
fields.answerD: how many hours per day you work

fields.text: By limiting work-in-progress, kanban helps to eliminate the  waste of...?
fields.answerC: rework

fields.text: Which of the following is not a benefit of kanban?
fields.answerA: allowing greater re-use of software components
fields.answerC: visualizing work

fields.text: Is every card system a kanban system?
Working in small batches, per our article, means releasing work...?
fields.answerC: every few months

fields.text: The term 'scrum' comes from the sport of _____, where all members must unite to advance the ball.
fields.answerC: golf

fields.text: A key principle of scrum is that...?
fields.answerA: customers can and will change their minds
fields.answerB: requirements must be locked down months in advance
fields.answerC: the analysis phase of software development must be completely separated from coding

fields.text: In scrum, the product owner has what role?
fields.answerB: being the voice of the customer
fields.answerC: garnering the profits from the release of the product
fields.answerD: being the only one allowed to speak at daily scrums

fields.text: The small batch principle of faster feedback would recommend what practice?
fields.answerA: only show your work to the customer once you are sure it is completely correct
fields.answerB: show early work stages to your team members, but never outside the team
fields.answerC: make your work visible as early and as often as possible

fields.text: Small batches help debugging because...?
fields.answerB: we will never have bugs if we work in small batches
fields.answerC: debuggers are small programs
fields.answerD: we know right away what area of the program caused a new problem

fields.text: As opposed to Toyota, American car manufacturers often used a _____ system of production.
fields.answerC: pull

fields.text: To eliminate the waste of over-production, we should...?
fields.answerA: build all things we think the customer might want in advance
fields.answerC: only build an MVP at first, and then see what more is needed

fields.text: In scrum, an epic is...?
fields.answerA: a poem like the Aeneid or the Illiad
fields.answerC: someone going on and on in a scrum
fields.answerD: a large body of work that can be broken down into smaller stories

fields.text: "No magic constants" means you should not...?
fields.answerA: scatter constants like 7, 12, or 3.14 through your program
fields.answerB: define constants to have values like "Harry Potter"
fields.answerC: use integer values in your code
fields.answerD: use an irrational number in your code

fields.text: Our functions should...?
fields.answerA: precisely embody the mathematical notion of a function
fields.answerB: do as many tasks as possible, since functions calls take time
fields.answerC: do one clearly definable task

fields.text: PEP 8 recommends that when indenting, we should use..?
fields.answerC: underscores

fields.text: When it comes to naming variables, we should...?
fields.answerC: keep everything in ALL Caps
fields.answerD: use the convention most widespread in our coding language

fields.text: Comments should be...?
fields.answerB: scattered through the code as widely as possible
fields.answerC: used for every line of code

fields.text: The best way to make your code understandable is...?
fields.answerA: to use as many comments as possible
fields.answerB: to use the longest variable names possible
fields.answerC: to write clear code

fields.text: The most important reason to use consistent indentation is...?
fields.answerA: it makes it easy for readers to see the control blocks
fields.answerB: to pass the tests of code-style tools
fields.answerC: it looks prettier that way

fields.text: According to PEP 8, constants should...?
fields.answerC: be_defined_with_underscores
fields.answerD: be defined on a per project basis

fields.text: If our program employs a database, we should define the data tables...?
fields.answerC: in both the code and database
fields.answerD: in one place used by both our code and the database

fields.text: Function and variable names should be...?
fields.answerC: hitting the mean between very short and very long

fields.text: DRY means your code should ...?
fields.answerC: Dally Really Youthfully

fields.text: PEP 8 recommends using blank lines in functions...?
fields.answerA: whenever the heck you want to
fields.answerC: never

fields.text: According to PEP 8, if we need a line break near a binary operator, it should come...?
fields.answerC: wherever looks good
fields.answerD: nowhere: rewrite the code so you don't need it

fields.text: Infrastructure as code can reduce costs, since...?
fields.answerA: code is lighter in weight than hardware
fields.answerB: executing in software is faster than doing so in hardware
fields.answerC: it relieves operations people of the time they would spend setting up infrastructure by hand

fields.text: Infrastructure as code speeds up deployment because...?
fields.answerB: running a script is faster than clicking through a GUI interface
fields.answerC: it eliminates the need for version control

fields.text: Infrastructure as code is less error-prone than manual deployment because...?
fields.answerA: it can be debugged once and that's that
fields.answerB: manual deployment is boring, and humans will make errors
fields.answerC: we can look over the code and reason about it

fields.text: A core DevOps principle is that automation is good because...?
fields.answerA: it gives machines the boring, repetitive work, and humans the interesting stuff
fields.answerB: it helps eliminate lots of jobs
fields.answerC: otherwise, lower-wage countries will have an advantage

fields.text: Which of the following are popular infrastructure-as-code tools?
fields.answerC: AWS, Google Cloud, and Azure

fields.text: Among the reasons infrastructure as code (IAC) is desirable is/are...?
fields.answerA: IAC can be put under version control
fields.answerB: IAC can be be automatically deployed
fields.answerC: IAC can be put through automated testing

fields.text: A disadvantage of Chef is...?
fields.answerA: it can't be used for large-scale deployment
fields.answerB: it is not designed for programmers
fields.answerC: using it requires knowledge of Ruby
fields.answerD: it can't be put under version control

fields.text: A disadvantage of Puppet is that users must...?
fields.answerC: commit to running Windows

fields.text: One reason we use Docker in our projects is...?
fields.answerA: it cuts down on memory usage
fields.answerB: it makes our unit testing simpler
fields.answerC: it provides automatic documentation for the source code
fields.answerD: it allows us to specify a local server that will be just like production

fields.text: When a Dockerfile says 'FROM Alpine-2.3' that means...?
fields.answerA: this will be a mountainous docker image
fields.answerB: the image being built will be based on the 'Alpine-2.3' image
fields.answerC: we will be running the 'Alpine-2.3' image

fields.text: A line in a Dockerfile that says 'RUN pip install -r requirements.txt' means...?
fields.answerA: once the container is launched, it will run that command
fields.answerB: if pip install is True, the container should RUN, or exit
fields.answerC: that command should be run to build the container
fields.answerD: nothing: that is an invalid command

fields.text: The command 'docker ps' will list...?
fields.answerC: all images currently installed on the system
fields.answerD: all images currently running on the system

fields.text: If we run the 'ps' command to list running processes both inside and outside a container, we will likely see more processes...?
fields.answerC: no telling
fields.answerD: you can't run it inside a container

fields.text: Infrastructure as code is important in the cloud (compared to old machine rooms) because...?
fields.answerA: we are likely to have more servers
fields.answerC: we often need to scale deployment up and down in a matter of minutes

fields.title: About
fields.content:
About the DevOps Course

A website for the NYU online DevOps course, built by Dr. Eugene Callahan, Vivek Bharti, Akshay Tambe, and the Fall 2018 and Spring 2019 DevOps students. The spring team is:

  • Gaurav Wadhawan
  • Shrey Gupta
  • Pulkit Aneja
  • Faiyaz Sundrani

The course is built using Django and other open source tools and is itself an open source project.

The requirements for a A-quality course project are:

  1. The project strictly follows the DRY principle: everything that must appear in multiple places in the project has a single source.
  2. All aspects of the project are under version control, including source, build scripts, graphics, documentation, and anything else related to the project.
  3. Make sure to test changes locally before committing.
  4. The project has automated testing with over 50% test coverage, and, if web-based, has Selenium tests.
  5. All of your code should pass a lint tool for the language you are using.
  6. For any aspects of the project that are built, there is an automated build process.
  7. Developers can work in a Docker container for development, and deploys can be done via a container. Furthermore, the containers themselves are built by scripts, not by hand.
  8. The project can successfully be deployed to the cloud.
  9. There is monitoring in place for the project.

fields.title: DevOpsLogo
Gloss
fields.content:
DevOps Course Glossary

Here is the glossary of terms for our course:

  • Agile Development: A method of developing software featuring frequent releases, adaptability to change, and close collaboration with customers.
    {% include 'Agile_Development.txt' %}
  • Anti-Pattern: A set of characteristics of some code structure or development practice that have been found to be common and harmful.
    Anti-Pattern found in: 
    devops/templates/gloss.html 
  • Automated Testing: Testing through scripts rather than "by hand."
    Automated Testing found in: 
    devops/templates/about.html 
    devops/templates/build.html 
    devops/templates/gloss.html 
    devops/templates/index.html 
    devops/templates/suite.html 
    devops/templates/test.html 
    devops/templates/work.html 
  • Azure DevOps: Microsoft's end-to-end DevOps solution.
    Azure DevOps found in: 
    devops/templates/gloss.html 
    devops/templates/index.html 
    devops/templates/suite.html 
  • Containerization: The process of packaging an application and everything it depends upon in a "container," then running it in its own virtual environment.
    {% include 'Containerization.txt' %}
  • Continuous Integration: (CI) The process of integrating different developers' work with high regularity.
    Continuous Integration found in: 
    devops/templates/build.html 
    devops/templates/cicd.html 
    devops/templates/gloss.html 
    devops/templates/suite.html 
    devops/templates/test.html 
  • Continuous Deployment: (CD) Regularly deploying new work into production, usually with every push to the master branch on the origin source-code control server.
    {% include 'Continuous_Deployment.txt' %}
  • Docker: The most popular tool for containerizing applications.
    Docker found in: 
    devops/templates/about.html 
    devops/templates/build.html 
    devops/templates/cicd.html 
    devops/templates/gloss.html 
    devops/templates/index.html 
    devops/templates/infra.html 
    devops/templates/suite.html 
  • DockerHub: A site hosting publically available Docker images.
    {% include 'DockerHub.txt' %}
  • git: Today's most popular version control system.
    {% include 'git.txt' %}
  • GitHub: A site hosting git repositories.
    {% include 'GitHub.txt' %}
  • image: The static version of a Docker container: we run the image to get a container.
    {% include 'image.txt' %}
  • Infrastructure-as-Code: (IAC) Using code to set up and provision servers, network connections, and so on.
    {% include 'Infrastructure-as-Code.txt' %}
  • Jenkins: A CI/CD tool that automates building and testing a product.
    Jenkins found in: 
    devops/templates/build.html 
    devops/templates/cicd.html 
    devops/templates/gloss.html 
    devops/templates/infra.html 
    devops/templates/suite.html 
  • Kanban: A tool for controlling work-in-progress and making visible who is working on what tasks.
    {% include 'Kanban.txt' %}
  • Kubernetes: An open-source tool for orchestrating containers.
    {% include 'Kubernetes.txt' %}
  • Lean Development: Similar to Agile Development; strong inheritance from Toyota Production Systems
    Lean Development found in: 
    devops/templates/gloss.html 
    devops/templates/work.html 
  • linting: Cleaning up source code by running a 'lint' tool that catches common coding errors.
    {% include 'linting.txt' %}
  • make: A venerable tool for automating builds.
    {% include 'make.txt' %}
  • Microservices: Tiny applications that do a single job, like authentication or scheduling deliveries.
    {% include 'Microservices.txt' %}
  • Monitoring: Software that "watches" an application and sends out alerts at signs of trouble.
    {% include 'Monitoring.txt' %}
  • Pattern: A set of characteristics of some code structure or development practice that have been found to be common and beneficial.
    {% include 'Pattern.txt' %}
  • repository: The 'database' of a version control system.
    {% include 'repository.txt' %}
  • Slack: A popular tool for communication in development teams; also, the "empty" periods that are necessary in a schedule for anyone to do creative work.
    {% include 'Slack.txt' %}
  • StatusCake: The monitoring software we are using in our course.
    {% include 'StatusCake.txt' %}
  • Test-Driven Development: A method of developing software that writes tests for a new feature first, then writes the feature.
    {% include 'Test-Driven_Development.txt' %}
  • Toyota Production Systems: (TPS) A lean manufacturing system put in place at Toyota in the 1960s, featuring flexible production and employee empowerment.
    {% include 'Toyota_Production_Systems.txt' %}
  • Version Control: A tool that allows users to keep multiple versions of a file, revert to earlier versions, compare versions, and so on.
    {% include 'Version_Control.txt' %}
